MCF7 cells indicated
no cytotoxic effects, confirming its biocompatibility. Confocal imaging

incubation, LS-1 (5 μM) effectively labeled HT-29 cells without
any external stimulation. In contrast, MCF7 cells showed minimal fluorescence
due to low levels of endogenous lysosomal H 2 2 Figure 2 in vivo Chen
and his research group developed a new series of NIR xanthene
dyes by substituting one end with a hydroxyl group, serving as an
on/off switch, and the other end with an amine group known for its
tunable spectroscopic properties. These were further modified with
various fused pyrrolidine or piperazine moieties. The photophysical
properties of the dyes (WR3–WR10) were systematically analyzed.
All dyes exhibited bathochromic shifts, fluorescence changes from
green to red (500–600 nm), and varying quantum yields. Among
them, WR3–WR6 showed the most promising performance due to
their high quantum yields (Ø = 0.19–0.2). As a proof of
concept, dye WR6 was used to develop two NIR probes, WSP-NIR and SeSP-NIR
for H 2 via 2 Scheme Figure 2 6 (A) Synthesis of different

revealing that
attaching the reaction moiety to the phenyl group at the 4 position
results in a stronger PET effect than attachment at the 5-position.
The cytotoxicity of Probe TMSDNPOB (0–50 μM) on HeLa
cells did not exhibit any toxicity, with survival rates of 90.9% and
86.2% at 10 μM and 50 μM, respectively. Due to its high
sensitivity, selectivity, biocompatibility, and low toxicity, TMSDNPOB
has been successfully applied to image H 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 in vitro in vivo Yao et al. designed a hepatocyte-targeting

HEPES buffer showed
a good linear response to increasing concentrations of Na 2 2 2 2 3 Ratiometric Probes and Their Advantages in Endogenous
H 2 Ratiometric probes for detecting
H 2 2 in vivo 2 2 2 2 3 2 4 Evaluating Clinical Translational
Relevance
of Fluorescent Probes for H 2 In this
review, we have evaluated a wide variety of fluorescent
probes with diverse fluorophores and reaction mechanisms for the detection
of endogenous H 2 3 2 2 3 2 Despite
their versatility, most small-molecule fluorescent probes
suffer from challenges related to in vivo 2 Photostability remains a major limitation
for many conventional
fluorophores, particularly under continuous or high-intensity excitation.
Only a few probes, such as TMSDNPOB Cytotoxicity is another important
consideration, probes such as
QL-N 3 2 2 Biodistribution and organ-specific accumulation have not been thoroughly
studied for most probes, as many were only evaluated at the in vitro 2 in vivo 2 Similarly, probe retention and clearance are critical for longitudinal
imaging and safety evaluation but are seldom reported. Moving forward,
it is essential to adopt standardized protocols to assess photostability,
absorption/emission stability, plasma protein binding, metabolic half-life,
biodistribution, and excretion profiles. Incorporating these parameters
early in the probe development pipeline will not only enhance translational
potential but also support regulatory approval pathways for clinical
imaging applications. 5 Next Generation Imaging Modalities
for Endogenous
H 2 Although this review primarily focuses
on traditional fluorescence
platforms (e.g., coumarins, rhodamines, cyanines), it is essential
to acknowledge emerging imaging modalities that are being increasingly
explored for detecting endogenous H 2 5.1 Near-Infrared II (NIR-II) Fluorophores NIR-II fluorophores (emission range 1000–1700 nm) enable deeper
tissue penetration, higher spatial resolution, and superior signal-to-background
ratios compared to conventional fluorophores. in vivo 3+ 2 2 in vitro in vivo 5.2 Chemiluminescent Probes Unlike fluorescence
probes, chemiluminescent probes emit light via a chemical reaction
and do not require external excitation, thereby eliminating background
autofluorescence and improving imaging sensitivity. 2 2 In vivo 2 5.3 Photoacoustic Imaging (PAI) Probes Photoacoustic imaging
probes absorb pulsed laser light and generate
ultrasound waves, enabling real-time, high-resolution, deep-tissue
imaging. While design complexity and image reconstruction are current
limitations, their advantages are compelling. 2 in vivo 5.4 Positron Emission Tomography (PET) Imaging PET imaging offers highly sensitive and quantitative molecular
imaging capabilities, outperforming fluorescence in terms of signal
quantification, photostability, and tissue penetration. 2 64 2 64 In vivo 2 5.5 Fluorescence Lifetime Imaging Microscopy (FLIM) FLIM measures the decay time of fluorophores in their excited state
to provide environmental information, offering resistance to intensity-based
artifacts. While theoretically well-suited for sensing microenvironmental
changes, no FLIM-based probes for H 2 While traditional fluorescence probes continue to
be foundational in H 2 2 Table 2 Overview of Emerging
Modalities for
Endogenous H 2 Methods Mechanism Aadvantages Refs NIR fluorescent probes Off-on response Rapid detection  Chemiluminescent probes Emission of light resulting
from a chemical reaction Enhances imaging depth and
signal-to-noise ratio without autofluorescence
and phototoxicity  Photoacoustic probe Light excitation and ultrasound detection  in situ 2 in vivo  PET imaging Selective retention and signal accumulation Non-invasive, real-time imaging and high selectivity  FLIM Based on the differences in the exponential
decay rate of the
fluorescence from a fluorescent sample Highly reliable
for quantitative imaging  6 Challenges Involved in Detection
Methods Hydrogen sulfide (H 2 2 2 2 Fluorescent probes have emerged as a powerful
tool for detecting
H 2 2 2 2 7 Conclusions and Future Directions Various
engineering strategies have been employed to optimize the
biocompatibility and functional properties of fluorescent probes for
H 2 2 2 in vitro in vivo 2 The advances discussed in this
review shed light on the complexity
of biological systems and demonstrate the potential of these probes
in biomedical research. Future efforts should focus not only on enhancing
the sensitivity and selectivity of fluorescent probes but also on
improving their biological stability, compatibility, and pharmacokinetic
profiles. Although a few probes have demonstrated their capability
to track H 2 in vivo in vitro in vivo 2 2 In the coming decade, significant progress is anticipated
in the
